title: Island Essentials
description: Everything you need to know before visiting Roatán — money, safety, water, healthcare, connectivity, and practical tips.

sections.title: Money & Payments
items: USD is widely accepted in tourist areas. You don't need to exchange money for most things.
The local currency is Honduran Lempira (HNL). Roughly 1 USD = 25 HNL. Useful for markets and local buses.
ATMs are available in Coxen Hole, French Harbour, and West End. There are NO ATMs in West Bay.
Visa and Mastercard are accepted at most tourist businesses. Amex is rare.
Carry small US bills ($1, $5, $10). Many vendors can't break a $50 or $100.
Tip in cash when possible — some restaurants' card machines don't have a tip option.

sections.title: Safety
items: Tourist areas (West Bay, West End, Sandy Bay) are generally safe during the day.
Exercise normal caution — don't flash expensive jewelry or electronics.
Avoid walking alone on dark roads at night, especially between West End and West Bay.
Use trusted taxi services. Ask your hotel or a local business for a recommendation.
Keep valuables in your hotel safe. Don't leave bags unattended on the beach.
Emergency number: 911 (limited response). Your hotel or resort is your best first contact.

sections.title: Water & Food Safety
items: Do NOT drink tap water. Bottled water is cheap and available everywhere.
Ice at tourist restaurants is typically made from purified water and is safe.
Street food and baleada stands are generally safe — look for busy, popular ones.
Seafood is incredibly fresh on Roatán. If it smells fishy, skip it — fresh fish doesn't smell.

sections.title: Sun & Reef Protection
items: Wear reef-safe sunscreen. Chemical sunscreens damage the coral reef. Zinc-based is best.
The sun is intense — reapply every 2 hours, especially after swimming.
Rash guards are better than sunscreen for snorkeling. Most dive shops sell them.
Don't touch coral, sea turtles, or marine life. It's both illegal and harmful.
Sand flies (no-see-ums) are worst at dawn and dusk on the beach. Bug spray helps.

sections.title: Getting Around
items: Taxis are the most common transport. Always negotiate the price BEFORE getting in.
Tuk-tuks (motorized three-wheelers) are cheap for short rides: $2-3 per person.
Water taxis connect West Bay, West End, and other coastal points. Fun and scenic.
Rental cars are available but roads can be rough. Drive on the right. Watch for speed bumps.
There is no Uber or rideshare on Roatán.
The main road runs the length of the island. West Bay to French Harbour is about 30 minutes.

sections.title: Connectivity
items: WiFi is available at most hotels, restaurants, and cafes in tourist areas.
Signal drops frequently between towns. That's why this app works offline.
Local SIM cards (Tigo or Claro) are available at the airport and shops in Coxen Hole for ~$10 with data.
Coverage is decent in West Bay, West End, and Coxen Hole. Spotty everywhere else.

sections.title: Healthcare
items: The public hospital is in Coxen Hole. Private clinics are in West End and French Harbour.
CEM (Centro de Especialidades Médicas) in French Harbour is the best private clinic on the island.
A hyperbaric chamber is available at Cornerstone Foundation in Sandy Bay for diving emergencies.
Pharmacies are available in Coxen Hole and French Harbour.
Travel insurance is strongly recommended. Medical evacuation to the mainland or US can be expensive.

sections.title: Tipping Guide
items: Restaurants: 10-15% if service charge not included. Check your bill first.
Bars: $1-2 per drink, or round up.
Dive masters: $5-10 per dive is customary and appreciated.
Tour guides: $5-10 per person for a half-day tour.
Taxi drivers: Not expected, but rounding up is a nice gesture.
Hotel housekeeping: $1-2 per day left in the room.
